body: @zackchase is this mergable?

One general comment:
x = [[1,2], [2]] produce a list, not an ndarray. If you actually call ndarray functions with it an error will be raised. This has confused some users.

not yet,i'd like to use one model tranning by 2 optimizers in my scenario Can it possible to support it without changing codes?

We can merge this first and I will PR a complete example.

On 04/15/2017 13:56, niluanwudidadi wrote:

For bugs or installation issues, please provide the following information.
The more information you provide, the more likely people will be able to help you.

Environment info

Operating System:Ubuntu16.04

Compiler:gcc 5.4

Package used (Python/R/Scala/Julia):Python

MXNet version:0.9.1

Or if installed from source:yes

Problem:

I have met a problem in multi-gpu rcnn training,when i use 4 1080, the speed is no faster than 2 gpu, and the terminal report the message "only 4 out of 12 GPU pairs are enabled direct access.The command is python train_end2end --gpu 0,1,2,3. Is the vgg network's reason?when I use resnet the speed is increases linearly with the number of gpu; and is there some parameters should set?

when i use python train_end2end --gpu 0 ,the speed is 5.4 samples/s
when i use python train_end2end --gpu 0,1 ,the speed is 8 samples/s
when i use python train_end2end --gpu 0,1,2 ,the speed is 7.4 samples/s
when i use python train_end2end --gpu 0,1,2,3 ,the speed is 6.4 samples/s

when i use python train_end2end --network resnet --gpu 0 ,the speed is 2.3 samples/s
when i use python train_end2end --network resnet --gpu 0,1 ,the speed is 4.0 samples/s
when i use python train_end2end --network resnet --gpu 0,1,2 ,the speed is 5.0 samples/s
when i use python train_end2end --network resnet --gpu 0,1,2,3 ,the speed is 5.7 samples/s

please fix the lint check. http://ec2-52-25-96-65.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/blue/organizations/jenkins/mxnet/detail/PR-5830/5/

I now `#include <cudnn.h>` to get access to `CUDNN_BN_MIN_EPSILON`. Please let me know if you prefer not to include and instead to compare to constant 1e-5.
If you launched it by ../../tools/launch.py, there is ../../tools/kill-mxnet.py to kill the process.
Would it be related to cython API? I can `import mxnet` on windows, which uses ctypes.
Thanks. I removed the unneeded import.

add `EvalMetric` argument for `EpochEndCallback`?
But the evaluation is done each batch, and the metric will be reset for validation dataset. It may not be clearly defined for what passes to `EpochEndCallback`.
@sifmelcara I ran lenet example for 5089 iters and could not reproduce this bug. I am running commit 96eb4f5a1a96e586be3558ab094b7d0139478365 from this pr: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5844

I boot the exact same hard drive on two computer, one have 1080Ti, the other have 1070.
The bug only appears when running on 1080Ti. And since
1. @GaiYu0 have TitanX, which also runs very fast.
2. I can avoid this bug by defer the execution of destructor of `Executor`.
3. I can avoid this bug by not using threaded engine.

I guess we need a fast GPU to reproduce this bug.
@sifmelcara well, I am able to reproduce @GaiYu0's issue with the same hardware on previous version of MXNet. But it seems to be fixed with 96eb4f5

I just tested it again, here is the steps I take to reproduce the bug.
1. `git clone https://github.com/eric-haibin-lin/mxnet.git --recursive`
2. `cd mxnet && git checkout cpp && git submodule update --recursive`
(now at 2e66d77)
3. `cp make/config.mk .`
4. set
```
USE_CUDA = 1
USE_CUDNN = 1
USE_CPP_PACKAGE = 1
USE_BLAS=openblas
ADD_CFLAGS += -I.... (open blas include dir)
ADD_LDFLAGS += -lopencv_core -lopencv_imgproc -lopencv_imgcodecs
USE_CUDA_PATH=... (cuda tool kit 8.0.61 path)
```
5. add `-L/location/to/libcuda.so` before `-lcuda` in `Makefile`
6. `make -j4`
7. `cp cpp-package/example/lenet.cpp .`
8.
```
g++ --std=c++11 -Iinclude \
                -Innvm/include \
                -Idmlc-core/include \
                -Icpp-package/include \
    -msse3 -Llib -lmxnet lenet.cpp
```
9. `export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:$(pwd)/lib`
10. get `train.csv`
11. run `./a.out`
12. get Segmentation fault (Here is the output https://pastebin.com/2yWkEhGB )

@javelinjs not sure to understand your point.
Basically, I just would like to have a way to access the value printed at https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/scala-package/core/src/main/scala/ml/dmlc/mxnet/module/BaseModule.scala#L388 from a callback function.
This looks hacky. Since we have backward inference now you can symbolically flatten and concat all weights into one. Just need to write a new op that split out n weights from a 1d long tensor

@piiswrong Do you think that the high-level norm clipping API is okay?
That is, we use
```python
mod.forward_bacward(...)
mod.clip_by_global_norm(...)
mod.update()
```

@jmerkow I'm using Dogs vs. Cats from kaggle.

making it a method of module seems weird
Need this!

Same thing happens here
[https://github.com/zhreshold/mxnet-ssd/issues/75](https://github.com/zhreshold/mxnet-ssd/issues/75)
@javelinjs tests passed
Have you used norm_clipping? If not, you can try the script in the PR https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5861
@sxjscience Is it the param `clip_gradient (float, optional)` in mxnet.optimizer.Optimizer? If so, yes, but it seems like not working. Or is my try wrong?
No, it's different. The clip_gradient parameter clips the maximum value. But the norm_clipping refers to the global L2 norm

Or I can put max_norm to the update function? In fact, TF and PyTorch adopt the similar strategy like the above.
TF example: https://github.com/tensorflow/models/blob/master/tutorials/rnn/ptb/ptb_word_lm.py#L177
Pytorch example: https://github.com/pytorch/examples/blob/master/word_language_model/main.py#L139
Setting clip_gradient is like to clip the global norm based on the infinity norm. While the norm_clipping means to clip based on the L2 norm, which is less restrictive.
ok

@yajiedesign 
Looks like unicode problem with windows. Can you reproduce?
should be some a describe use error encoding,i try to reproduce
Let's merge?

@tangjiasheng @piiswrong I find that the revised script also cannot reproduce the PTB result. The reason is that the training split is different from the standard approach. For the current example, we split the PTB data to multiple sentences and group different sentences into a minibatch. While in the original version, the raw_data is split into multiple segments and truncated BPTT is used for each segment.

See https://github.com/tensorflow/models/blob/master/tutorials/rnn/ptb/reader.py and https://github.com/wojzaremba/lstm/blob/master/data.lua#L48
I don't see any reason not to, so I think you can go forward to merge.

@sxjscience Yes, I'm running your new script and also find the same performance.  Besides data processor, is the converge rate comparable with using SGD? I found it also needs more epoches to converge into a low PPL.
While using adam, the converge rate seems better. But you know, TF only uses SGD inside this example.

@tangjiasheng I'm trying to reproduce the TF version exactly so I try to revise it to use the same optimization parameter. But it turns out that the way we train the model and evaluate the model is different from TF. Will need to correct it.
@sxjscience Thanks for your efforts. will you please update this issue if any progress could be got?
@tangjiasheng Yes, I'll let you know once I've got the result.
:) Follow the discussion.

I did a complete fresh build on ubuntu and osx and both worked fine.

"uniform" and "normal" were already taken before. There is no real change associated with them except that now they are merely aliases.

I can't say for sure which one is best. The only thing i can tell you is that it works for me with 16.04 with an nvidia gtx1060. 

Possible outlier... :)

shared_weight = mx.sym.Variable("shared_weight", shape=(3, 64, 3, 3))
conv1 = mx.sym.Convolution(data=data, weight=shared_weight, name="conv1", ...)
conv2 = mx.sym.Convolution(data=conv1, weight=shared_weight, name="conv2",...)

I also met this problem.
I tried to bind two executors **with partially shared parameters**. If I use `exe1.outputs[0].asnumpy()` in the training iteration (to inspect whether there is any problem with the training setup), the training process freeze. If I comment out all `asnumpy()` lines, training goes smoothly. If I bind without any parameter shared, then there is no problem with `asnumpy()` call
Try to disable the unnecessary lint checks
Both are okay. But I think 16.04 should be better.
One way of removing this from module would be to add a update_all method to optimizer that clip the gradient.

@piiswrong, thanks for pointing this out. i'll review and update the doc.
Can you tell what specifically you are referring to?

@Soonhwan-Kwon Thanks for the comment. But it seems that there was some issue with the way i setup my environment for running the example. I fixed the issue, with help from @qiyuangong in issue #5094.

For those who are also facing this issue, please follow the steps mentioned by @qiyuangong in the issue #5094 to get the scripts working as expected. Am now able to successfully run the example given on multi CPU cluster, and hence closing this issue.
@zihaolucky @tangjiasheng The PTB validation and testing results are much more reasonable now. You can try the `lstm_ptb.py` in the PR .
So much better. 👍

Tangential note: we should want to roll back the 5px padding-bottom on the li class. It's affecting all the lists on the site including the Table of Contents. Sorry about the conflicting requests and thanks for moving quickly on everything!
Is this ready to merge? @zackchase
@piiswrong just requested one minor change (an NDArray that should be `NDArray`). Otherwise looks good to me!

Thanks!

can I get the parameters visible after trainning ？so I can rebuild a only predicted model online
paddle gives the user  different layer's parameters visible through different files

I have done the same thing with ZF-net too, and finally i got 60.89 mAP on voc_2007_test  with model trained with voc_2007_trainvel and 66.78 with voc_2007_trainval+voc_2012_trainval(this is not an average result, just run once). I just ignored the difference of LRN between mxnet and caffe, but the important thing is that, you should finetune all the layers in ZF, while VGG was trained with conv1 and conv2 fixed.

Did the Jenkinsfile take effect???

Using the model API, we could load the trained model and predict, without re-creating the network.
But in the module API, I think it expects you to create the network and bind it before you can predict.
Is my understanding correct?
Can I safely use the checkpoint saved by the Module API and load it using the FeedForward/model API and predict? will there be any side effects?
Also, will you be adding this support (predicting without requiring explicit bind) in the module API as well?

The last three bads means build failure, and other bad means performance problem.

Since the operator names are changed from `uniform` and `normal` to `random_uniform` and `random_normal` in `sample_op.cc`, I think we should also change them in `sample_op.cu` to prevent them from taken before. See #5890
